Lotto: Secure Participant Selection against Adversarial Servers
in Federated Learning

Zhifeng Jiang11{}^{\text{1}}  Peng Ye11{}^{\text{1}}  Shiqi He2,∗2{}^{\text{2},*}  Wei Wang11{}^{\text{1}}  Ruichuan Chen33{}^{\text{3}}  Bo Li11{}^{\text{1}}
11{}^{\text{1}}Hong Kong University of Science and Technology  22{}^{\text{2}} University of Michigan  33{}^{\text{3}} Nokia Bell Labs
Abstract

In Federated Learning (FL), common privacy-preserving technologies, such as secure aggregation and distributed differential privacy, rely on the critical assumption of an honest majority among participants to withstand various attacks. In practice, however, servers are not always trusted, and an adversarial server can strategically select compromised clients to create a dishonest majority, thereby undermining the system’s security guarantees. In this paper, we present Lotto, an FL system that addresses this fundamental, yet underexplored issue by providing secure participant selection against an adversarial server. Lotto supports two selection algorithms: random and informed. To ensure random selection without a trusted server, Lotto enables each client to autonomously determine their participation using verifiable randomness. For informed selection, which is more vulnerable to manipulation, Lotto approximates the algorithm by employing random selection within a refined client pool. Our theoretical analysis shows that Lotto effectively restricts the number of server-selected compromised clients, thus ensuring an honest majority among participants. Large-scale experiments further reveal that Lotto achieves time-to-accuracy performance comparable to that of insecure selection methods, indicating a low computational overhead for secure selection.

††∗Work partially done as a research assistant at HKUST.

1 Introduction

Edge devices, such as smartphones and laptops, are becoming increasingly powerful and can now collaboratively build high-quality machine learning (ML) models using device-collected data [42]. To protect data privacy, large companies like Google and Apple have adopted federated learning (FL) [50] for tasks in computer vision (CV) and natural language processing (NLP) across client devices [38, 62, 76]. In FL, a server dynamically samples a small subset of clients from a large population in each training round. The sampled clients, aka participants, compute individual local updates using their own data and upload only the updates to the server for global aggregation, without revealing the training data [15].

However, simply keeping client’s data undisclosed is not sufficient to preserve data privacy. Recent studies have demonstrated that sensitive data can be leaked through individual updates during FL training [35, 80, 73, 82], and it is also possible to infer a client’s data from trained models [58, 20, 63, 52] by exploiting their ability to memorize information [20, 63]. To minimize data leakage, current FL systems employ secure aggregation techniques [16, 15, 9] to ensure that adversaries only learn the aggregate updates, not individual ones. Additionally, these systems may use distributed differential privacy (DP) [41, 6, 64] to limit the extent of data leakage from the aggregate update (section 2.2). Since the server may not always be trusted, these privacy-preserving approaches commonly assume that the majority of the participants act honestly and can jointly detect and prevent server misbehavior.

Nonetheless, this assumption may not hold in practice, as an adversarial server can strategically select compromised clients that collude with it. Note that this is a feasible attack. While the entire client population is large, the target number of participants in each round is often limited to a few hundred for efficiency purposes [15]. Consequently, even if the majority of the population is honest (e.g., 99% out of 100,000 clients), the server can still select a sufficient number of adversaries to create a dishonest majority among participants.

The presence of a large number of compromised participants undermines the aforementioned privacy-preserving approaches, resulting in significant vulnerabilities. As shown in section 2.3, the privacy guarantees provided by distributed DP degrade rapidly as the dishonest cohort expands [41, 6, 64]. Furthermore, secure aggregation can only tolerate a certain proportion of clients colluding with the server; exceeding this limit would allow the adversary to reconstruct a client’s update [16]. It is hence crucial to minimize the proportion of participants that the server can manipulate during the client selection process.

Despite its importance, this problem remains largely unaddressed in the literature. The main challenge lies in the use of a central server in the cross-device FL scenarios [42]. In the absence of efficient peer-to-peer communication across a vast array of heterogeneous devices [77, 44], the server serves as a central hub facilitating message exchanges between clients. Since the server is untrusted, an honest client may not have a ground truth view of other clients, such as their availability, utility, and integrity. Consequently, it is difficult for a client to audit whether the server has correctly executed the prescribed participant selection algorithm, as doing so requires ground truth knowledge of and/or inputs from other clients.

In this paper, we present Lotto, a novel system that enables secure participant selection in FL for the first time. Our key insight is that while an honest majority may not exist among participants produced by the server, it should hold among the entire client population, given the prohibitive cost of creating and operating a large number of adversarial clients [50, 9, 57]. Therefore, by incorporating verifiable randomness to the selection process, we can prevent the adversarial server from selecting an arbitrary number of dishonest participants.

Specifically, to achieve secure random selection [50], Lotto allows each client in the population to determine its participation in a training round by computing verifiable random functions (VRFs) [29, 51] using its secret key and public inputs. Once a client decides to participate, Lotto collects the referred randomness, along with the associated VRF proof, for other participants to verify the generation of the randomness. This approach ensures that each client’s participation is provably independent of, fair to, and unpredictable for other clients. Yet, an adversarial server may still exploit this process to grow the dishonest cohort, for example, by sending incorrect and/or a selected subset of messages. Lotto further mitigates such misconduct by enabling honest clients to verify critical messages. Lotto provides a provable guarantee that the compromised fraction of selected participants remains minimum, thereby maintaining the security guarantees offered by secure aggregation and distributed DP (section 3.4).

Lotto is also capable of securing more advanced algorithms, referred to as informed selection, which are widely used in FL to judiciously select the best-performing participants for optimal training efficiency [81, 53, 70, 21, 45, 43]. Given that these algorithms rely on client-specific measurements (e.g., processing speed and data quality) that are difficult to verify, Lotto does not attempt to precisely follow their selection logic. Instead, it approximates them by reducing an informed selection problem to a random one. To do so, it first allows the server to refine the client pool by excluding a small fraction of low-quality clients based on the specified measurements. Lotto then performs secure random selection from the refined pool. Although an adversarial server may still attempt to manipulate this process by excluding honest clients, the security of our random selection ensures that any advantage it gains is provably small (section 3.5).

We have implemented Lotto as a library (section 4) and evaluated its performance with various FL tasks in a large EC2 cluster configured to emulate a cross-device scenario (section 5).222Lotto is available at https://github.com/SamuelGong/Lotto. Compared to insecure selection algorithms, Lotto slightly increases the duration of each training round by less than 10% while achieving comparable or even better time-to-accuracy performance.

2 Background and Motivation

In this section, we begin by providing an overview of the standard FL workflow (section 2.1). We then discuss the privacy concerns and prevalent privacy-preserving approaches that critically rely on an honest majority among participants (section 2.2). Following this, we highlight the privacy vulnerabilities that arise when encountering a dishonest majority (section 2.3) and ultimately present the motivation for our work.

2.1 Federated Learning

Federated learning (FL) [50, 42] emerges as a new private computing paradigm that enables a large number of clients to collaboratively train a global model under the orchestration of a server. The standard FL workflow is an iterative process that comprises three steps in each training round [15]. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{1}⃝ Participant Selection: the server samples a subset of eligible clients from the entire population as participants, where the eligibility criteria may include factors such as charging status and device being connected to an unmetered network. \raisebox{-1.0pt} {2}⃝ Local Training: the server distributes the global model to each participant, who then trains the model using its private data to compute a local update. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{3}⃝ Model Aggregation: the server collects local updates from participants and computes an aggregate update. This step is often coupled with additional privacy enhancement techniques (section 2.2). The server then uses the aggregate update to refine the global model. As participants only expose their local updates instead of raw data to other parties, FL adheres to the data minimization principle [42, 27] mandated by many privacy regulations [69]. Consequently, FL has been deployed to facilitate a broad range of edge intelligence applications [38, 62, 76].

2.2 Enhancing Data Privacy in FL

Despite the fact that client data is not directly revealed during the FL training process, extensive research has demonstrated that it is still possible to disclose sensitive data through data reconstruction or membership inference attacks using individual updates or trained models. For example, an adversary can accurately reconstruct a client’s training data from its local updates [35, 80, 73, 82]; it can also infer from a trained language model whether a client’s private text has been used in the training set [58, 20, 63, 52]. To effectively control the exposure of clients’ data against these attacks, FL systems commonly employ two privacy enhancement techniques: secure aggregation and distributed differential privacy.

Secure Aggregation (SecAgg) [16].   SecAgg is a secure multi-party computation (SMPC) protocol that enables the server to learn only the sum of clients’ updates and nothing beyond that. In SecAgg, each participant i𝑖i first generates two key pairs (s​ki1,p​ki1)𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑘1𝑖𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑘1𝑖(sk^{1}_{i},pk^{1}_{i}), (s​ki2,p​ki2)𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑘2𝑖𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑘2𝑖(sk^{2}_{i},pk^{2}_{i}), where the public keys (p​ki1,p​ki2)𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖2(pk_{i}^{1},pk_{i}^{2}) are shared with others. Each pair of participants (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) then engage in a key agreement to derive two shared keys si,j=KA.Agree​(s​ki1,p​kj1)subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗KA.Agree𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑘1𝑖𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑘1𝑗s_{i,j}=\texttt{KA.Agree}(sk^{1}_{i},pk^{1}_{j}) and ci,j=KA.Agree​(s​ki2,p​kj2)subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗KA.Agree𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑘2𝑖𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑘2𝑗c_{i,j}=\texttt{KA.Agree}(sk^{2}_{i},pk^{2}_{j}). Each participant i𝑖i then uses a pseudorandom number generator to derive a pairwise mask, 𝒑i,j=PRNG​(si,j)subscript𝒑𝑖𝑗PRNGsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗\bm{p}_{i,j}=\texttt{PRNG}(s_{i,j}), for each other participant j𝑗j, and adds it to its update following 𝒚i=𝒙i−∑j<i𝒑i,j+∑j>i𝒑i,jsubscript𝒚𝑖subscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝒑𝑖𝑗subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝒑𝑖𝑗\bm{y}_{i}=\bm{x}_{i}-\sum_{j<i}\bm{p}_{i,j}+\sum_{j>i}\bm{p}_{i,j}. As a result, after all participants’ masked updates are aggregated, the pairwise masks cancel out, i.e., ∑𝒚i=∑𝒙isubscript𝒚𝑖subscript𝒙𝑖\sum\bm{y}_{i}=\sum\bm{x}_{i}.

In case of client dropout, SecAgg removes the pairwise masks of the dropped participants to ensure that the remaining pairwise masks can still cancel out when aggregated. To achieve this, each participant i𝑖i secret-shares its key s​ki1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑘1𝑖sk^{1}_{i} to each other participant j𝑗j using a t𝑡t-out-of-n𝑛n secret sharing scheme, where t𝑡t is the minimum number of participants required to recover the shared key. Therefore, if participant i𝑖i later drops out, there are enough remaining clients (≥tabsent𝑡\geq t) who can help the server reconstruct its key s​ki1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑘1𝑖sk^{1}_{i}, which can then be used to recover the missing pairwise masks.

However, there remains a security concern in that the server can falsely claim the dropout of participant i𝑖i to recover its pairwise masks: removing these masks, the server can uncover participant i𝑖i’s local update xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}. To address this concern, SecAgg introduces an additional mask 𝒒i=PRNG​(bi)subscript𝒒𝑖PRNGsubscript𝑏𝑖\bm{q}_{i}=\texttt{PRNG}(b_{i}) where bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} is independently generated by participant i𝑖i and secret-shared with each other. The modified masking process for participant i𝑖i becomes:

𝒚i=𝒙i​−∑j<i𝒑i,j+∑j>i𝒑i,j⏟A+𝒒i⏟B.subscript𝒚𝑖subscript𝒙𝑖subscript⏟subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝒑𝑖𝑗subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝒑𝑖𝑗𝐴subscript⏟subscript𝒒𝑖𝐵\bm{y}_{i}=\bm{x}_{i}\underbrace{-\sum_{j<i}\bm{p}_{i,j}+\sum_{j>i}\bm{p}_{i,j}}_{A}+\underbrace{\bm{q}_{i}}_{B}. (1)

By requiring that the server can only request secret shares of either s​ki1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖1sk_{i}^{1} (to recover part A𝐴A if i𝑖i drops out) or bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} (to recover part B𝐵B if i𝑖i reports its update) from other remaining participants, SecAgg ensures that part A𝐴A and B𝐵B cannot be removed simultaneously, and the secrecy of 𝒙isubscript𝒙𝑖\bm{x}_{i} is preserved. Subsequent works, such as SecAgg+ [9], have been proposed to reduce the runtime overhead and increase scalability.

Distributed Differential Privacy (DP) [6, 41].   Simply concealing individual local updates using SecAgg is insufficient as client data can still leak through the aggregate updates. Differential privacy [28, 31] can prevent this by ensuring that no specific client’s participation significantly increases the likelihood of any observed aggregate update by potential adversaries. This guarantee is captured by two parameters, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and δ𝛿\delta. Given any neighboring training datasets D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} that differ only in the inclusion of a single participant’s data, an aggregation procedure M𝑀M is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private if, for any given set of output R𝑅R, Pr​[M​(D)∈R]≤eϵ⋅Pr​[M​(D′)∈R]+δPrdelimited-[]𝑀𝐷𝑅⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrdelimited-[]𝑀superscript𝐷′𝑅𝛿\textrm{Pr}[M(D)\in R]\leq e^{\epsilon}\cdot\textrm{Pr}[M(D^{{}^{\prime}})\in R]+\delta. Therefore, a change in a participant’s contribution yields at most a multiplicative change of eϵsuperscript𝑒italic-ϵe^{\epsilon} in the probability of any output R𝑅R, except with probability δ𝛿\delta.

To achieve a specific privacy goal (ϵG,δG)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐺subscript𝛿𝐺(\epsilon_{G},\delta_{G}) in an R𝑅R-round training, the aggregate update needs to be perturbed by a random noise r𝑟r calibrated based on ϵGsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐺\epsilon_{G}, δGsubscript𝛿𝐺\delta_{G}, R𝑅R, and the sensitivity of the aggregated update ΔΔ\Delta (defined as its maximum change caused by the inclusion of a single client’s data). Given the use of SecAgg, the required level of noise can be achieved without relying on the (untrusted) server by having each participant i𝑖i add an even share of the random noise risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} to its local update, i.e.,

∑iri\overunderset​(ϵG,δG)​-DP​R,Δ∼r.similar-to\overundersetsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐺subscript𝛿𝐺-DP𝑅Δabsentsubscript𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖𝑟\sum_{i}r_{i}\mathrel{\overunderset{(\epsilon_{G},\delta_{G})\textrm{-DP}}{R,\Delta}{\scalebox{4.0}[1.0]{$\sim$}}}r. (2)

This DP model is referred to as distributed DP in the literature [42], given its distributed fashion of noise addition.

2.3 Privacy Loopholes in Common Defenses

Strong Assumption on Honest Majority.   The above approaches commonly assume that the majority of participants are honest, relying on them to detect or prevent the server’s misbehavior. However, this assumption often proves inaccurate due to the necessity of participant selection in FL systems. While the overall population may be extensive, FL usually involves a limited number of sampled clients at each training round, typically in the range of a few hundred [15, 42]. This limitation arises because including additional clients beyond a certain threshold only yields marginal improvements in terms of convergence acceleration [50, 72]. Therefore, even if the majority (e.g., 99%) of the population (e.g., 105superscript10510^{5}) consists of honest clients, there are still a sufficient number of dishonest clients (e.g., 103superscript10310^{3}) that the server can freely select, thereby forming a dishonest majority among the participating clients. Without an honest majority across participants, the above approaches encounter significant security vulnerabilities.

Case #1: SecAgg.   SecAgg safeguards a participant i𝑖i’s plaintext update 𝒙isubscript𝒙𝑖\bm{x}_{i} from server probing by distributing secret shares of s​ki1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖1sk_{i}^{1} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} among other participants and requiring them to disclose only the shares of either secret to the server (section 2.2). However, this can not be achieved if a malicious server colludes with a sufficiently large fraction of clients.

Consider a scenario with s𝑠s participants, x𝑥x of which collude with the server. Let t𝑡t denote the threshold used by the t𝑡t-out-of-n𝑛n secret sharing scheme in SecAgg. As depicted in Figure 1(a), when x≥2​t−s𝑥2𝑡𝑠x\geq 2t-s, the server can identify two separate sets of honest participants, each containing at least t−x𝑡𝑥t-x members. In this case, by announcing participant i𝑖i’s contradictory dropout outcome to either set, the server can collect at least t−x𝑡𝑥t-x secret shares for both s​ki1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖1sk_{i}^{1} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}. Combining them with the shares provided by the x𝑥x colluding clients, the server can reconstruct s​ki1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖1sk_{i}^{1} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}, simultaneously. Ultimately, SecAgg fails to protect the local update of participant i𝑖i, as implied by Equation 1.

Case #2: Distributed DP.   Distributed DP, being built upon SecAgg, inherits the aforementioned security vulnerability. When the number of dishonest participants surpasses a specific threshold (2​t−n2𝑡𝑛2t-n as mentioned earlier), a malicious server can deduce the precise local update of participant i𝑖i, which is perturbed solely by its noise share risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} (but not r𝑟r).

Even if this threshold is not exceeded, the security of distributed DP can still be impacted by dishonest participants. If they choose not to add any noise to their local updates, the cumulative noise added to the aggregated update will fall below the required level. This results in increased data exposure, causing the system to exhaust its privacy budget more rapidly than planned. To demonstrate this issue in a practical FL scenario, we conduct an analysis on a testbed where 700 clients collaborate to train a CNN model over the FEMNIST dataset for 50 rounds. Each round involves 70 randomly selected clients, with the task of noise addition distributed equally among all participants. However, dishonest participants will abstain from adding any noise. Figure 1(b) illustrates that as the fraction of dishonest participants increases (while remaining below the SecAgg’s threshold mentioned earlier), the privacy deficit grows explosively, regardless of the prescribed privacy budget. For example, when 40% participants are dishonest, training with a global privacy budget ϵG=6subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐺6\epsilon_{G}=6 ends up consuming an ϵGsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐺\epsilon_{G} of 11.8 at the 50th round.

3 Lotto: Secure Participant Selection

Taking the first stab at the mentioned issues, we present Lotto, a framework that secures participant selection in FL. We first establish the threat model (section 3.1), formalize the selection problem (section 3.2), and briefly introduce the cryptographic primitives used (section 3.3). Next, we describe how Lotto accomplishes our goal in two scenarios: random selection (section 3.4) and informed selection (section 3.5). We finally provide security (section 3.6) analysis for these methods.

3.1 Threat Model

Cross-Device Scenarios with Server-Mediated Network.   Each client has a private authenticated channel established with the server, ensuring that their transmitted messages cannot be eavesdropped on by external parties. We do not assume a peer-to-peer network among clients due to concerns regarding efficiency and scalability. Instead, clients rely on the server to mediate communication between them.

Public Key Infrastructure (PKI).   We assume a PKI that facilitates the registration of client identities and the generation of cryptographic keys on their behalf. During the setup phase, each client i𝑖i registers its public key, denoted as (i,pkir​e​g(i,pk_{i}^{reg}), to a public bulletin board maintained by the PKI. The bulletin board only accepts registrations from clients themselves, preventing malicious parties from impersonating honest clients. Additionally, the PKI is responsible for generating the required public/secret key pair for client i𝑖i to use in Lotto, (p​kiL​o​t​t​o,s​kiL​o​t​t​o)𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜(pk_{i}^{Lotto{}},sk_{i}^{Lotto{}}). The PKI encrypts the secret key s​kiL​o​t​t​o𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜sk_{i}^{Lotto{}} using p​kir​e​g𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝑟𝑒𝑔pk_{i}^{reg} to securely transmit them to client i𝑖i. Meanwhile, the public key p​kiL​o​t​t​o𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜pk_{i}^{Lotto{}} is registered on the public bulletin board. The communication with the PKI is not mediated by the server.

Malicious Server with Dishonest Minority in Population.   We assume a malicious server colluding with a subset of clients in the population and they can arbitrarily deviate from the protocol. They may send incorrect or chosen messages to honest clients, abort or omit messages, or engage in Sybil attacks [30] to increase the portion of clients under their control. However, we assume that the majority of the population is honest, as simulating or compromising a large number of clients incurs prohibitive costs for the adversary. The costs involved in registering numerous identities with a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) operated by a qualified trust service provider [16, 9], or operating a client botnet at scale would be excessively high [57]. We do not assume an honest majority across participants, as the selection outcome depends entirely on the adversary if the protocol is insecure (section 2.3).

3.2 The Participant Selection Problem

In the FL literature, participant selection is commonly approached in two forms, both of which we aim to safeguard.

Random Selection.   The Federated Averaging (FedAvg) algorithm [50], considered the canonical form of FL, adapts local SGD [65, 37] on a randomly selected subset of clients during each round. To achieve random selection, the server can perform subsampling without replacement, where a subset of the population is chosen uniformly at random. Alternatively, it can conduct Bernoulli sampling, where each client is independently included with the same probability. We focus on the former as it guarantees a fixed sample size.

Informed Selection.   Given the large heterogeneity in device speed and/or data characteristics, several FL advancements go beyond random sampling by employing informed selection algorithms [81, 53, 70, 21, 45, 43]. These algorithms leverage client-specific measurements to identify and prioritize clients who have the greatest potential to rapidly improve the global model. Among these measurements, some can be directly monitored by the server, e.g., response latencies, while the others rely on clients’ self-reporting, e.g., training losses.

For example, Oort, the state-of-the-art informed algorithm, ranks each client i𝑖i with a utility score UiO​o​r​tsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑂𝑜𝑟𝑡U_{i}^{Oort} that jointly considers the client’s system speed and data quality:

UiO​o​r​t=|Bi|​1|Bi|​∑k∈BiL​o​s​s​(k)2⏟Data​quality×(Tti)𝟙​(T<ti)×α⏟System​speed.subscriptsuperscript𝑈𝑂𝑜𝑟𝑡𝑖subscript⏟subscript𝐵𝑖1subscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝑘subscript𝐵𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑠𝑠superscript𝑘2Dataqualitysubscript⏟superscript𝑇subscript𝑡𝑖1𝑇subscript𝑡𝑖𝛼SystemspeedU^{Oort}_{i}=\underbrace{|B_{i}|\sqrt{\frac{1}{|B_{i}|}\sum_{k\in B_{i}}Loss(k)^{2}}}_{\mathrm{Data\ quality}}\times\underbrace{(\frac{T}{t_{i}})^{\mathds{1}(T<t_{i})\times\alpha}}_{\mathrm{System\ speed}}. (3)

The first component is the aggregate training loss that reflects the volume and distribution of the client’s dataset Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}. The second component compares the client’s completion time tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} with the developer-specified duration T𝑇T and penalizes any delay (which makes the indicator 𝟙​(T<ti)1𝑇subscript𝑡𝑖\mathds{1}(T<t_{i}) outputs 1) with an exponent α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. Oort prioritizes the use of clients with high utility scores for enhanced training efficiency.

Design Goal.   Let n𝑛n represent the population size, with c𝑐c being the number of dishonest clients, and s𝑠s the target number of participants in a training round. Our goal, regardless of the selection approach, is to minimize the number of dishonest participants, denoted by x𝑥x. Ideally, x𝑥x should resemble c/n⋅s⋅𝑐𝑛𝑠c/n\cdot s, where c/n𝑐𝑛c/n is the base rate of dishonest clients in the population (which is presumably small, e.g., 1%, as assumed in section 3.1). However, for practical purposes, we allow for a slight relaxation of this ideal goal. We aim to align x𝑥x with η​s𝜂𝑠\eta s, where η∈(0,1)𝜂01\eta\in(0,1) is small enough to ensure the security of the privacy-preserving protocol implemented in the remaining FL steps.

3.3 Cryptographic Primitives

We first provide a quick primer on the cryptographic primitives involved in Lotto’s solution to achieve our objective.

Verifiable Random Function (VRF) [51, 29].   A VRF is a public-key PRF that provides proof that its outputs were computed correctly. It consists of the following algorithms:

  • •

    (p​k,s​k)←$currency-dollar←𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘absent(pk,sk)\xleftarrow{\$} VRF.keygen(1κ)superscript1𝜅(1^{\kappa}). The key generation algorithm randomly samples a public/secret key pair (p​k,s​k)𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘(pk,sk) from the security parameter κ𝜅\kappa.

  • •

    (β,π)←←𝛽𝜋absent(\beta,\pi)\leftarrowVRF.eval(x)s​k{}_{sk}(x). The evaluation function receives a binary string x𝑥x and a secret key s​k𝑠𝑘sk and generates a random string β𝛽\beta and the corresponding proof π𝜋\pi.

  • •

    {0,1}←←01absent\{0,1\}\leftarrowVRF.ver(p​k,x,β,π)𝑝𝑘𝑥𝛽𝜋(pk,x,\beta,\pi). The verification function receives a public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk and three binary strings x𝑥x, β𝛽\beta, and π𝜋\pi, and outputs either 0 or 1.

A secure VRF should have unique provability and pseudorandomness. The former requires that for every public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk and input x𝑥x, there is a unique output β𝛽\beta for which a proof π𝜋\pi exists such that the verification function outputs 1. The latter requires that no adversary can distinguish a VRF output without the accompanying proof from a random string.

Signature Scheme.   A signature scheme allows a message recipient to verify that the message came from a sender it knows. It consists of the following algorithms:

  • •

    (p​k,s​k)←$currency-dollar←𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘absent(pk,sk)\xleftarrow{\$} SIG.gen(1κ).superscript1𝜅(1^{\kappa}). The key generation algorithm randomly samples a public/secret key pair (p​k,s​k)𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘(pk,sk) from the security parameter κ𝜅\kappa.

  • •

    σ←←𝜎absent\sigma\leftarrowSIG.sign(m)s​k{}_{sk}(m). The sign function receives a binary string m𝑚m and a secret key s​k𝑠𝑘sk and generates a signature σ𝜎\sigma.

  • •

    {0,1}←←01absent\{0,1\}\leftarrowSIG.ver(p​k,m,σ)𝑝𝑘𝑚𝜎(pk,m,\sigma). The verification function receives a public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk and two strings m𝑚m and σ𝜎\sigma, and outputs either 0 or 1.

For correctness, a signature scheme must ensure that the verification algorithm outputs 1 when presented with a correctly generated signature for any given message. For security, we require that no PPT adversary, when given a fresh honestly generated public key and access to a signature oracle, can produce a valid signature on a message on which the oracle was queried with non-negligible probability.

Pseudorandom Function (PRF) [36].   A secure PRF(x)k{}_{k}(x) is a family of deterministic functions indexed by a key k𝑘k that map an input x𝑥x into an output in such a way that the indexed function is computationally indistinguishable from the output of a truly random function with input x𝑥x.

3.4 Secure Random Selection

A faithful execution of random selection naturally achieves our goal (section 3.2). However, enforcing this in the presence of a malicious server poses two key challenges:

  • •

    Correctness (C1): A malicious server can deviate from random selection while falsely claiming adherence to the protocol. How can clients prevent such misbehavior?

  • •

    Consistency (C2): Even if the protocol is faithfully executed, how can we ensure that the participants in the subsequent workflow are indeed those who were selected?

Self-Sampling with Verifiable Randomness.   To address C1, we propose a self-sampling approach where each individual client in the population is responsible for determining whether it should participate in a training round based on publicly available inputs. The key intuition is that honest clients, which form the majority of the population, have a strong incentive to follow a reasonable selection plan due to concerns about preserving their own privacy. For security, we need to tackle the following adversarial issues simultaneously:

  • •

    T1.1: Ensuring that dishonest clients cannot participate without following the prescribed self-sampling protocol.

  • •

    T1.2: Ensuring that honest clients who choose to participate do not get arbitrarily omitted by the dishonest server.

To accomplish T1.1, Lotto introduce verifiable randomness to the self-sampling process to allow each participant to verify the integrity of other peers’ execution. Specifically, we utilize a VRF with range [0,m)0𝑚[0,m), and assume that the FL training needs to randomly sample s𝑠s out of n𝑛n clients for a specific training round r𝑟r. At the beginning of the round, the server first announces s𝑠s, n𝑛n, r𝑟r to all clients in the population. Each client i𝑖i then generates a random number βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} and the associated proof πisubscript𝜋𝑖\pi_{i} using its private key s​kiL​o​t​t​o𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜sk_{i}^{Lotto{}} via βi,πi=subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝜋𝑖absent\beta_{i},\pi_{i}= VRF(r)s​kiL​o​t​t​o{}_{sk_{i}^{Lotto{}}}(r). To achieve an expectation of s𝑠s sampled clients, only those clients with βi<s​m/nsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑠𝑚𝑛\beta_{i}<sm/n will claim to participate by uploading their βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i}’s and πisubscript𝜋𝑖\pi_{i}’s to the server, while the remaining clients abort. Next, the server takes all the surviving clients P𝑃P as participants and dispatches the collected {βi,πi}i∈Psubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝜋𝑖𝑖𝑃\{\beta_{i},\pi_{i}\}_{i\in P} to each of them. Finally, each participant i𝑖i verifies the validity and eligibility of its peers’ randomness, i.e., checking if VRF.val​(p​kjL​o​t​t​o,r,βj,πj)=1VRF.val𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑗𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑟subscript𝛽𝑗subscript𝜋𝑗1\textrm{{VRF.val}}(pk_{j}^{Lotto{}},r,\beta_{j},\pi_{j})=1 and βj<s​m/nsubscript𝛽𝑗𝑠𝑚𝑛\beta_{j}<sm/n for each j∈P𝑗𝑃j\in P. It aborts upon any failure, or refers to this set of participants throughout the remaining stages of the training round.

By security of VRFs (section 3.3), if all the s​kiL​o​t​t​o𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜sk_{i}^{Lotto{}}’s are uniformly random (guaranteed by the PKI as implied in section 3.1), this process is pseudorandom where each client is selected equally likely with probability s/n𝑠𝑛s/n. Also, the participation of a dishonest client i𝑖i will not be acknowledged by honest clients, if its associated randomness falls outside the publicly known range [0,s​m/n)0𝑠𝑚𝑛[0,sm/n) or fails to pass the VRF verification test parameterized by the public key p​kiL​o​t​t​o𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜pk_{i}^{Lotto{}} issued by the PKI.

Over-Selection with Indiscriminate Removal.   While VRFs securely achieve Bernoulli sampling, our primarily desired form of random selection is subsampling without replacement (section 3.2). To achieve a fixed sample size, Lotto further employs over-selection with indiscriminate removal based on the above process. Specifically, instead of directly targeting s𝑠s sampled clients, Lotto slightly increases the expected sample size by a factor α>1𝛼1\alpha>1. In this case, clients identify themselves as candidate participants C𝐶C when their associated βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i}’s satisfy βi<α​s​m/nsubscript𝛽𝑖𝛼𝑠𝑚𝑛\beta_{i}<\alpha sm/n. Next, the server fairly samples s𝑠s candidates out of C𝐶C uniformly at random to finalize the set of participants P𝑃P, if the total number of candidates is no less than the required sample size s𝑠s. Otherwise, Lotto aborts the current round. As we observed in practice (Figure 2), a small value of α𝛼\alpha around 1.3 suffices to sample enough clients with high probability. A more rigorous analysis is provided in Appendix A.

Constraints on Population Size against Malicious Coordination.   Although the use of VRFs prevents the server from freely selecting a dishonest client to participate, it is still possible for it to exploit the process and increase the ratio of dishonest participants. This can be done during the finalization of participants, where the server can remove honest candidates, not just the ones with randomly chosen indices. To prevent such misconduct (T1.2), a simple fix is to enforce execution integrity using trusted execution environments (TEEs) [26]. However, the feasibility of TEEs depends not only on the server’s hardware support but also on clients’ trust in the hardware manufacturers. Also, TEE security is not infallible, as it remains susceptible to side-channel attacks [22, 68].

Fortunately, while enforcing execution integrity could be complex, the server’s ability to grow the ratio of dishonest participants can still be controlled indirectly by reasonable use of parameters in Lotto. To ensure that dishonest clients remain a minority among the participants, regardless of how the server removes honest candidates, it is sufficient to guarantee that the number of dishonest candidates x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} is significantly smaller than the target number of participants s𝑠s. This way, even if the server deliberately includes all dishonest candidates in the final participants, as long as the number of participants is required to be fixed at s𝑠s, the remaining participants, which constitute the majority, have to be honest clients. To establish an upper bound for 𝔼​[x′]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑥′\mathbb{E}[x^{\prime}], we require a sufficiently large population size n𝑛n, because 𝔼​[x′]=c⋅α​s/n𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑥′⋅𝑐𝛼𝑠𝑛\mathbb{E}[x^{\prime}]=c\cdot\alpha s/n and all parameters cannot be manipulated by the server except for n𝑛n. Thus, Lotto let honest clients agree upon a minimum acceptable population size, denoted as nminsubscript𝑛minn_{\text{min}}, and abort if the announced n𝑛n falls below this threshold.

Inter-Client Consistency via Signature Scheme.   While we have ensured that each participant i𝑖i333We do not consider the views of non-participant clients in a round, as they are not of concern regarding data privacy. receives a selection outcome where each member appears with probability lower-bounded, the issue of guaranteeing identical outcomes among all participants remains. To address this concern, Lotto employs a secure signature scheme, which operates as follows:

  • •

    Each client signs its received selection outcome Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} with its registration secret key s​kir​e​g𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝑟𝑒𝑔sk_{i}^{reg}, generating a signature σi=subscript𝜎𝑖absent\sigma_{i}= SIG.sign(r||Pi)s​kir​e​g{}_{sk_{i}^{reg}}(r||P_{i}) where |||| denotes concatenation.

  • •

    After collecting all signatures from a set of clients P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime}, the server broadcasts to them the set {(j,σj)}j∈P′subscript𝑗subscript𝜎𝑗𝑗superscript𝑃′\{(j,\sigma_{j})\}_{j\in P^{\prime}} containing the received signatures.

  • •

    Upon receiving {(j,σj)}j∈Pi′subscript𝑗subscript𝜎𝑗𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑃′𝑖\{(j,\sigma_{j})\}_{j\in P^{\prime}_{i}}, each client i𝑖i verifies the correctness of all signatures and ensures that the corresponding participant lists are consistent with its observed one, i.e., Pi′=Pisubscriptsuperscript𝑃′𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖P^{\prime}_{i}=P_{i} and SIG.ver(pkjr​e​g,r||Pi,σj)(pk_{j}^{reg},r||P_{i},\sigma_{j}) = 1 for ∀j∈Pi′for-all𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑃′𝑖\forall j\in P^{\prime}_{i}. If any failure occurs during verification, the client aborts.

In summary, by addressing C1 with the above design, honest participants are ensured to proceed only with a consistent participant list with each member randomly presenting with probability less than α​s/nm​i​n𝛼𝑠subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛\alpha s/n_{min}. This upper bound remains invariant during the training, as it is fully determined by public values. Hence, it can be used to derive practical security guarantees (section 3.6), regardless of misbehaviors exhibited by the server, e.g., claiming an inaccurate n𝑛n.

Inherent Inter-Stage Consistency with SecAgg.   Ensuring consistency in participant sets used by the server throughout the entire FL workflow (C2) poses inherent difficulties. On one hand, if the privacy-preserving protocol used in the later stage mandates that all participants observe a genuine selection outcome to ensure valid computation, C2 is inherently addressed without additional measures. However, if the server can secretly involve a participant set different from the announced one while still observing meaningful exchanged messages, the attainability of C2 becomes an open question, as honest participants cannot detect such deception with limited trusted source of information (section 3.1).

Fortunately, the protocol commonly employed in the remaining workflow is SecAgg (or the distributed differential privacy built upon it) (section 2.2), where the server has an incentive to uphold the actual selection outcome during the entire training. First, it gains no advantage by secretly involving additional dishonest clients. In SecAgg integrated with Lotto, an honest participant i𝑖i establishes secure channels with peers solely by using the public keys p​kjr​e​g𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑗𝑟𝑒𝑔pk_{j}^{reg} contained in the selection outcome Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} finalized by Lotto. Therefore, it will not share any additional secrets with clients outside of Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}, even if they participate in the halfway. Second, the server will not pretend arbitrarily many dropout events of selected honest participants, e.g., by omitting their messages. This is because SecAgg enforces a minimum number of participants (i.e., t𝑡t) remaining in the final stage, beyond which the aggregation will abort without providing any meaningful information.

Full Protocol: Client-Centric v.s. Server-Centric.   Putting it all together, the above design of Lotto can be summarized by Figure 3. We refer to this algorithm as Client-Centric since the selection step primarily occurs at the client end. Client-Centric effectively achieves the security goal outlined in section 3.2. We provide a detailed analysis of its security in section 3.6 and assess its complexity in appendix B.

It is worth noting that there exists an alternative design that may initially appear to be a natural choice. This design retains the core elements of Client-Centric but relies on the server to perform the random selection. Specifically, for each client i𝑖i in the population, the server uses a PRF with range [0,m)0𝑚[0,m) to generate a random value βi=PRFp​kiL​o​t​t​o​(r)subscript𝛽𝑖subscriptPRF𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑡𝑡𝑜𝑟\beta_{i}=\textrm{{PRF}}_{pk_{i}^{Lotto{}}}(r), and selects it as a participant if βi<α​s​m/nsubscript𝛽𝑖𝛼𝑠𝑚𝑛\beta_{i}<\alpha sm/n. The selection outcome, along with the associated randomness, is communicated to each participant for verification purposes. We refer to this design as Server-Centric. Intuitively, Server-Centric offers the same security guarantee as Client-Centric does in a single training round, as it also provides honest clients with a consistent participant list with members presenting equally likely within a preset probability upper bound.

However, Server-Centric faces an additional security challenge during multiple-round training. As the selection outcome relies solely on public inputs, a malicious server can accurately predict, before online training, whether an honest participant i𝑖i will be selected in a specific round r𝑟r. This predictability opens up opportunities for the adversary to exploit the system. For instance, during the participant finalization stage in each round, the server in Server-Centric can deliberately ensure that the most frequently appearing candidate is not removed. In the context of DP training, this deterministic coordination behavior implies a weaker level of privacy guarantee. We give a rigorous security comparison in Appendix D. Considering the similarity of the empirical runtime overhead between the two designs (section 5.2), we adopt Client-Centric as Lotto primary design for its stronger security.

3.5 Secure Informed Selection

Challenges.   Unlike random selection, informed selection does not inherently incorporate randomness, but heavily relies on client measurements (section 3.2). This presents two challenges in our pursuit of controlling the number of dishonest participants. Consider Oort [45] as an example, where a client’s response latency and training loss are employed as proxies for system speed and data quality, respectively (section 3.2). First, the adversary can manipulate these metrics for selecting more colluding clients. Lacking a ground truth view on these metrics, detecting such deception is hard for honest clients. Second, even if adversaries refrain from actively corrupting any measurements, they can still involve more dishonest clients by genuinely improving their system speed or data quality. Such exploitation is more covert to detect.

Approximation with Introduced Randomness.   To side-step the above issues, Lotto introduces randomness to the selection process by incorporating secure random selection (section 3.4) to approximate a given informed algorithm. The server first refines the population by excluding a fraction d𝑑d of clients with the lowest utility, based on the original criteria employed in the algorithm. It then applies secure random selection to the refined population. For example, if the original algorithm prioritizes the fastest clients, Lotto approximates it by first excluding the slowest d𝑑d of clients before random selection.

Note that Lotto does not enforce the integrity of the refinement process due to the aforementioned challenges, and thus the server has the flexibility to purposely exclude honest clients, not just the “bad” clients. However, we can tolerate such adversarial scenarios to some extent by ensuring that d𝑑d is small. For instance, as illustrated in Figure 4, if the server is allowed to exclude 20% of the population, the maximum increase in the base rate of dishonest clients in the refined population would be less than 25%. In Lotto, the regulation of d𝑑d can be achieved by appropriately setting nm​i​nsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛n_{min}, i.e., the minimum accepted size of the remaining population (section 3.4).

Population refinement can be considered as a preprocessing step taken before secure random selection (Figure 3). Hence, Lotto’s approach to informed selection inherits all the security properties of its random selection, as discussed in section 3.6.

Effectiveness of Population Refinement.   Consider the following single-metric scenario without loss of generality: the original algorithm selects the best s𝑠s clients out of the initial population of size ni​n​i​tsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡n_{init} based on a metric X𝑋X (Case A). When employing Lotto, s𝑠s clients are randomly selected from the refined population of size n=ni​n​i​t​(1−d)𝑛subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡1𝑑n=n_{init}(1-d) (Case B).

The extent to which Lotto approximates the original algorithm relies on the disparity in participant quality, as measured by X𝑋X, between Case A and Case B. This difference, in turn, depends on the distribution of X𝑋X across the initial population. Intuitively, Lotto best approximates the original algorithm when X𝑋X follows a long-tailed distribution (e.g., power-law distributions [25]), where the majority of the population is considered “good" and only a small fraction is deemed “bad”. In this case, Lotto can exclude almost all the relatively few "bad" participants. For example, suppose that X𝑋X is the smaller, the better, and it follows Zipf’s distribution parameterized by p𝑝p, such that the X𝑋X value of the i𝑖i-th worst client is proportional to i−psuperscript𝑖𝑝i^{-p}. In this case, precluding the worst d𝑑d of the initial population enhances the quality of the worst client that can be selected by (1−d)−psuperscript1𝑑𝑝(1-d)^{-p}, as shown in Figure 5.

At the other extreme, there could be a scenario where the majority of clients are classified as "bad" while only a minority of them are deemed "good." In this case, our approximation may not yield participants of sufficiently high quality compared to the original algorithm. We acknowledge this limitation yet contend that this compromise is a necessary cost in order to secure the selection process.

Handling Multiple-Metric Algorithms.   In the cases where the original algorithm incorporates two or more independent metrics, a straightforward approach to conducting population refinement is the Or strategy which excludes the worst clients based on one of the metrics. Alternatively, we can also adopt the And strategy that excludes clients that perform poorly in all metrics simultaneously. Furthermore, if the original informed algorithm combines the information from the two metrics into a single comprehensive metric, such as what Oort defines as the utility score (section 3.2), there further exists a Joint strategy which directly relies on this single metric for population refinement. We advocate the adoption of Or due to its superiority demonstrated in empirical experiments (section 5.3).

3.6 Security Analysis

Secure Random Selection.   Our primary objective is to limit the number of dishonest participants (section 3.2). To assess how well Lotto’s random selection achieves it, we focus on the properties exhibited by the finalized participant list P𝑃P. Consider a population of size n𝑛n, with c𝑐c clients being dishonest. We denote by s𝑠s the desired number of sampled clients, and x𝑥x the number of clients that an adversary could manipulate among the selected participants. Let nm​i​nsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛n_{min} be the population threshold, m𝑚m the randomness range, and α𝛼\alpha the over-selection factor. Theorem 1 holds true despite the adversary’s misbehavior.

Theorem 1 (Security of Random Selection).

If the protocol proceeds without abortion, for any η∈(0,1)𝜂01\eta\in(0,1), the probability that the number of dishonest participants, i.e., x𝑥x, exceeds η​s𝜂𝑠\eta s is upper bounded as

Pr​[x>η​s]≤1−∑i=0⌊η​s⌋(ci)​(1m​⌊α​s​mnm​i​n⌋)i​(1−1m​⌊α​s​mnm​i​n⌋)c−i.Prdelimited-[]𝑥𝜂𝑠1superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝜂𝑠binomial𝑐𝑖superscript1𝑚𝛼𝑠𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑖superscript11𝑚𝛼𝑠𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑐𝑖\textrm{Pr}[x>\eta s]\leq 1-\sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor\eta s\rfloor}\binom{c}{i}\left(\frac{1}{m}\lfloor\frac{\alpha sm}{n_{min}}\rfloor\right)^{i}\left(1-\frac{1}{m}\lfloor\frac{\alpha sm}{n_{min}}\rfloor\right)^{c-i}.

While the proof is deferred to Appendix C, Figure 6(a) depicts the rapid reduction of the right-hand side of the above inequality as the threshold η𝜂\eta grows in a practical scenario. Here, we vary the population size n𝑛n, while the number of colluding clients in the population set to c=103𝑐superscript103c=10^{3}, and the target number of participants as s=n/1000𝑠𝑛1000s=n/1000. We consider α=1.3𝛼1.3\alpha=1.3, m=2256𝑚superscript2256m=2^{256}, and nm​i​n=nsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑛n_{min}=n. For example, when the population size n=2×105𝑛2superscript105n=2\times 10^{5}, employing insecure random selection results in a probability of 1 for the event where the fraction of dishonest participants exceeds 5%. However, with Lotto, this probability becomes negligible, approximately 1.3×10−71.3superscript1071.3\times 10^{-7}.

We further incorporate Theorem 1 into the analysis of SecAgg and distributed DP and establish the following corollaries. The related proof can also be found in Appendix C.

Corollary 1 provides insights into the robustness of Lotto in maintaining the security of SecAgg, while Corollary 2 outlines the end-to-end privacy guarantees offered by Lotto when integrated with existing distributed differential privacy (DP) systems. In the specific case discussed above, when SecAgg is used with t𝑡t set larger than 0.53​s0.53𝑠0.53s444The feasible range of t𝑡t SecAgg is (0.5​s,s]0.5𝑠𝑠(0.5s,s] in the malicious settings [16]., the probability of SecAgg’s failure diminishes to less than 8.9×10−68.9superscript1068.9\times 10^{-6} when employing Lotto. Otherwise, the probability is 1 (Figure 6(b)). Building upon SecAgg with t=0.7​s𝑡0.7𝑠t=0.7s, if DSkellam [6] is implemented as the distributed DP protocol, with a target δ=1/n𝛿1𝑛\delta=1/n and using a consistent noise multiplier, training over FEMNIST (refer to the related settings in section 5.1), Lotto guarantees a moderate privacy cost of ϵ=1.8italic-ϵ1.8\epsilon=1.8. In contrast, insecure selection would result in a prohibitive cost of ϵ=265italic-ϵ265\epsilon=265 (Figure 6(c)).

Secure Informed Selection.   Population refinement in our informed selection can be considered as a preprocessing step that precedes our random selection (section 3.5). Hence, the security guarantee provided by our informed selection can be derived from that of our random selection. Assume that the initial population consists of ni​n​i​tsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡n_{init} clients, with c𝑐c being the number of dishonest clients. Denote by n𝑛n the size of the refined population. As the server can act maliciously by deliberately excluding honest clients, in the worst case, all c𝑐c dishonest clients remain in the refined population. Therefore, the security guarantee can be derived by directly applying Theorem 1.

4 Implementation

We have implemented Lotto as a library easily pluggable into existing FL systems with 1235 lines of Python code. It operates within the server and on each client, interacting with the underlying framework of an FL execution.

System Workflow.   Figure 7 shows how Lotto interacts with the FL execution frameworks during participant selection. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{1}⃝ Pool Confirmation: the framework forms a pool with clients meeting eligibility properties (e.g., battery level) and forward their identities and characteristics (e.g., latency) to Lotto. In case of informed selection, the server-end refines the pool by excluding those clients who have the worst utility, based on the original criteria applied in the original algorithm. Lotto next proceeds to random selection and has two variants. \raisebox{-0.4pt}{\footnotesize2a}⃝ Server-Centric Selection: the server-end over-selects participants from the pool as candidates using PRFs. \raisebox{-0.4pt}{\footnotesize2b}⃝ Client-Centric Selection: for each client in the pool, the server-end informs its client-end to self-sample with VRFs. Clients meeting the participation conditions report their results and become candidates. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{3}⃝ Mutual Verification: the server fairly selects the target number of clients from the candidate list as participants. It then helps each participant check its peers’ qualification and their seen outcomes. \raisebox{-1.0pt}{4}⃝ Participant Finalization. The FL framework proceeds with the selection outcome output by Lotto and starts FL training.

Cryptographic Instantiation.   Secure PRFs can be implemented with a cryptographic hash function in conjunction with a secret key, and we use HMAC-SHA-256. For secure signature schemes, we utilize Ed25519 [10], an elliptic-curve-based signature scheme. Both of the above choices are implemented leveraging the cryptography Python library [1]. We implement VRFs using ECVRF-Ed25519-SHA512-Elligator2 as specified in [3] using the codebase provided by [5].

5 Evaluation

We evaluate Lotto’s effectiveness in various FL training testbeds. The highlights of our evaluation are listed below.

  1. 1.

    Compared to insecure selection methods, Lotto introduces at most 10% runtime overhead and negligible extra network usage across different participation scales (section 5.2).

  2. 2.

    In the case of informed selection, the adoption of Lotto achieves comparable or even superior training efficiency compared to that of insecure methods (section 5.3).

5.1 Methodology

Datasets and Models.   We run two common categories of applications with three real-world datasets of different scales.

  • •

    Image Classification: the FEMNIST [18] dataset, with 805k images classified into 62 classes, and a more complicated dataset OpenImage [2] with 1.5M images spanning 600 categories. We train a CNN [41, 6], and MobileNet V2  [55] with 0.25 as width multiplier to classify the images in FEMNIST and OpenImage, respectively.

  • •

    Language Modeling: the large-scale Reddit dataset [4]. We train next-word predictions with Albert model [46].

Cluster Setup.   We launch an AWS EC2 r5n.8xlarge instance (32 vCPUs, 256 GB memory, and 25 Gbps network) for the server and one c5.xlarge (4 vCPUs and 8 GB memory) instance for each client, aiming to match the computing power of mobile devices. We also throttle clients’ bandwidth to fall at 44Mbps to match the average mobile bandwidth [24].

Hyperparameters.   For local training, we use the mini-batch SGD for FEMNIST and OpenImage and AdamW [48] for Reddit, all with momentum set to 0.9. The number of training rounds and local epochs are 50 and 2 for both FEMNIST and Reddit and 100 and 3 for OpenImage, respectively. The batch size is consistently 20 across three tasks, while the learning rate is fixed at 0.01 for FEMNIST and 8e-5 for Reddit, respectively. For OpenImage, the initial learning rate is 0.050.050.05, and decreases by a factor of 0.98 after every 10 rounds. For model aggregation, we apply weighted averaging [50] protected by the SecAgg [16] protocol (section 2.2).

Baselines.   In evaluating random selection, we compare Lotto against Rand [50], the naive random selection protocol. As for informed selection, we compare Lotto against Oort [45], the state-of-the-art informed algorithm designed for maximum training efficiency. Both Oort and Rand are considered insecure as the server has the freedom to include dishonest clients. For Lotto, we primarily evaluate the Client-Centric approach, while also demonstrating its efficiency similarity with the Server-Centric approach (section 3.4).

5.2 Execution Efficiency

We assess the time performance and network overhead of Lotto. To study the impact of the federation scale, we vary the population size from 100 to 400 to 700. The target sampled clients are proportionately set to 10, 40, and 70, respectively.

Lotto Induces Acceptable Overhead in Time.   Figure 8 summarizes the average round time in random selection, broken down into two parts: local training (‘train’), and the remaining workflow operations (‘other’). It also shows the runtime portion of the latter, helping the reader understand the characteristics of various FL tasks. When compared to Rand, Lotto implemented with Client-Centric incurs a time cost of less than 6%, 8%, and 10% for population sizes of 100, 400, and 700, respectively. Moreover, the overhead for Server-Centric is 1%, 4%, and 3%, respectively. Such acceptable overhead is expected as Lotto is built on lightweight security primitives (3.4). As for informed selection, all the observed trends are identical to those reported in Figure 8 (with Rand replaced by Oort). We thus defer the results to Appendix E for brevity.

Lotto Induces Negligible Overhead in Network.   Figure 9 illustrates the network footprint per round at the server end during random selection, categorized into two components: the outbound part (‘send’) and the inbound part (‘recv’). As one can see, Lotto introduces less than 1% additional network footprint across all evaluated tasks and all participation scales. This can be attributed to the fact that the predominant communication overhead in FL is the transmission of the model, rather than other auxiliary information. For example, when training over Reddit with 700 clients, model transfer in a round yields a network footprint of approximately 6.6 GB to the server (Fig. 9(c)). In contrast, the extra cost brought by Client-Centric and Server-Centric are merely 1.3 MB and 0.3 MB, respectively. As for informed selection, again, we defer them to Appendix E given the identical implications.

Client-Centric v.s. Server-Centric.   The preceding analysis emphasizes Lotto’s minimal time and network costs, irrespective of whether it is implemented using a Client-Centric or Server-Centric approach. Since both approaches demonstrate comparable efficiency in practice, we recommend adopting the latter, as it ensures enhanced security through the unpredictability of selection outcomes, as outlined in section 3.4.

5.3 Effectiveness of Informed Selection

We next evaluate the effectiveness of Lotto’s approximation strategies in achieving the objectives of the target informed selection algorithm. We focus on the Client-Centric implementation of Lotto and use the 700-client testbed (section 5.2).

Heterogeneous Environment.   The realistic datasets we employ (section 5.1) already demonstrate data heterogeneity, as they are partitioned by the original data owners. Figure 10(a) to 10(c) provides a visualization of clients’ data quality, as measured by Oort’s definition (the first term in Equation (3)) without loss of generality. Snapshots of clients’ status are taken across different rounds of the training. On the other hand, for the adoption of Oort to be meaningful, we need to additionally emulate hardware heterogeneity. To this end, we set the response latencies of clients to consistently follow a Zipf distribution parameterized by a=1.2𝑎1.2a=1.2 (moderately skewed), regardless of the specific FL task, as illustrated in Figure 10(d).

The Or Strategy Outperforms Other Choices of Lotto.   Lotto considers various strategies for population refinement when approximating the target informed algorithm (section 3.5). Here, we compare them using a consistent exclusion threshold of 20%. Under this threshold, a client is excluded if it ranks in the bottom 20% in either system speed or data quality (Or); in both metrics (And); or in the comprehensive utility score (Equation (3)) defined by Oort (Joint). Additionally, we include the Rand method as a baseline reference. As illustrated in 11, Or and Joint constantly outperforms Rand, while And fails to surpass it in certain cases, e.g., FEMNIST (Fig. 11(a)). This can be attributed to the independent distributions of system speed and data quality across clients. As there are only a few clients that rank in the bottom 20% simultaneously for both metrics (observed to be ≤\leq5% of the population), the number of clients that And excludes is inadequate. Between Or and Joint, we advocate the use of the former due to its consistently superior performance and fix its use for the remaining analysis.

Lotto Achieves Comparable or Even Superior Performance to Oort.   To examine the time-to-accuracy performance, we set the target accuracy at 69.8% and 27.6% for FEMNIST and OpenImage, respectively. For Reddit, we set the target perplexity (lower values are better) at 1010. As depicted in Figure 11, Lotto achieves nearly identical performance to Oort in OpenImage, and it even surpasses Oort by 1.1×\times for both FEMNIST and Reddit. In comparison to Rand, Lotto outperforms it by 2.1×\times, 3.0×\times, and 1.6×\times in FEMNIST, OpenImage, and Reddit, respectively. Note that we have accounted for the disparity in execution efficiency between Lotto and baselines (section 5.2) for fairness of comparison. These results underscore the significant enhancement in the quality of selected clients through population refinement, specifically employing the Or strategy with a 20% exclusion factor, making it competitive with Oort which cherrypicks the best clients. Overall, the randomness introduced by Lotto for ensuring security guarantees (section 3.6) does not compromise the training efficiency achieved by insecure methods.

6 Discussion and Future Work

General Solutions for Inter-Stage Consistency.   Lotto does not explicitly ensure consistent reference to a participant list throughout the entire FL workflow. This is because, for SecAgg that this paper primarily focuses on, any inconsistent reference by the server offers no significant advantage in probing clients’ data (section 3.4). This applies to other secure aggregation protocols, such as SecAgg+ [9], the state-of-the-art follow-up work of SecAgg. Similar to SecAgg, SecAgg+ ensures that each participant will not share secrets with clients beyond its verified participant list, and also includes controllable dropout tolerance that can prevent the server from pretending the dropout of numerous honest participants. However, it would be beneficial to explore general solutions for achieving inter-stage consistency when combining Lotto with other potential protocols in the future.

7 Related Work

Privacy-Preserving Aggregation with Malicious Server.   Numerous protocols have been proposed to enable a server to learn the sum of multiple inputs without gaining access to individual inputs. However, many of these protocols assume an honest-but-curious server [40, 60, 61] or a trusted third party [13, 23, 32], which has limited practicality. Only the commonly used SecAgg [16] and SecAgg+ [9] and a few other protocols [49, 47, 78, 54] allow for a malicious server. To further control the information leakage through the sum, distributed DP protocols [41, 6, 64, 39] provide rigorous privacy guarantees by combining the DP noise addition with SecAgg. However, both secure aggregation and distributed DP are still vulnerable to the privacy risks posed by a dishonest majority among participants, while Lotto takes the initiative to tackle this issue by secure participant selection.

Secure Federated Training against Adversaries.   Besides probing data privacy, an adversary may also compromise the global model performance during FL training [8, 7, 12, 33, 56, 67, 71]. Several approaches have been proposed to mitigate these attacks, e.g., by employing certifiable techniques during local training [19, 74], or applying dimension-wise filtering [79, 11], vector-wise scaling [66, 34], or vector-wise filtering [14, 59, 75, 17] to model aggregation. These works back up Lotto with robust model performance, whereas Lotto enhances data privacy by secure participant selection.

8 Conclusion

In FL, various aggregation protocols have been developed to enhance clients’ data privacy. However, the participant selection mechanisms they rely on remain vulnerable to manipulation by adversarial servers. In this paper, we have proposed Lotto, an FL system that addresses the critical issue of secure participant selection against an adversarial server. Lotto provides two selection algorithms, random and informed, both of which effectively restrict the number of server-selected compromised clients, thereby ensuring an honest majority among participants. Theoretical analysis and large-scale experiments demonstrate that Lotto not only provides increased security but also achieves time-to-accuracy performance comparable to that of insecure selection methods.

Appendix A Over-Selection

In Lotto’s random selection, a fixed sample size is achieved via over-selection with indiscriminate removal. The following theorem shows how the choice of the over-selection factor α𝛼\alpha affects the success probability of selecting enough participants in one go.

Theorem 2 (Effectiveness of Over-Selection).

Using an over-selection factor α>0𝛼0\alpha>0, the described process in Lotto results in at least s𝑠s candidates with probability of 1−∑i=0⌊s−1⌋(ni)​pi​(1−p)n−i1superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑠1binomial𝑛𝑖superscript𝑝𝑖superscript1𝑝𝑛𝑖1-\sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor s-1\rfloor}\binom{n}{i}p^{i}(1-p)^{n-i} where p=α​s/n𝑝𝛼𝑠𝑛p=\alpha s/n.

Appendix B Complexity Analysis

Let n𝑛n be the initial population size, and s𝑠s the target number of sampled clients. We also abuse the symbol n𝑛n to represent the refined population size, as both should be of the same magnitude. For secure random selection, Client-Centric induces an overhead of O​(1)𝑂1O(1) and O​(n+s2)𝑂𝑛superscript𝑠2O(n+s^{2}) to the server’s computation and communication, respectively, while those incurred to a selected client are O​(s)𝑂𝑠O(s) and O​(s)𝑂𝑠O(s), respectively. In Server-Centric, the computation and communication for the server are O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) and O​(s2)𝑂superscript𝑠2O(s^{2}), respectively, while those for a selected client are O​(s)𝑂𝑠O(s) and O​(s)𝑂𝑠O(s), respectively. For informed selection, the overhead of the server’s computation in Client-Centric becomes O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n), while other terms of overhead remain the same, compared to random selection.

Appendix D Client-Centric v.s. Server-Centric

As indicated in section 3.4, we consider the Client-Centric design as the primary approach for Lotto’s random selection, because it offers superior security guarantees in the context of multiple-round training. In order to measure the disparity, we focus on multiple-round DP training, where the privacy cost is contingent upon the client selected for the maximum number of times, assuming a fixed noise multiplier. With the Client-Centric approach, the server cannot determine which client will be selected in a specific round r𝑟r until the selection process takes place. Consequently, a malicious server cannot definitively identify the very participant who will turn out to be the most frequent candidates during the finalization of participants for each round. In other words, the server can only reserve it with some probability less than 1. In contrast, with the Server-Centric approach, the server can reserve the aforementioned client with certainty due to the predictability of the selection outcomes even before the training begins. As a result, compared to Client-Centric, Server-Centric provides the adversary with less randomness, which has implications for its security guarantees. More formally, when it comes to training with distributed DP, from Theorem 1 we can derive the following corollary for Server-Centric:

Corollary 3 (Controlled Privacy Cost in Distributed DP, II).

Let π𝜋\pi be the distributed DP protocol parameterized by σ𝜎\sigma and built atop SecAgg with aggregation threshold t𝑡t. Given target δ𝛿\delta, an R𝑅R-round FL training with π𝜋\pi and Lotto’s random selection (Server-Centric) achieves (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, where

ϵitalic-ϵ\displaystyle\epsilon =min0≤k≤min⁡{c,2​t−s}0≤r≤Rpk+qr<δ⁡Eπ​(s,k,r,σ,1−1−δ1−pk−qr),absentsubscript0𝑘𝑐2𝑡𝑠0𝑟𝑅subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑞𝑟𝛿subscript𝐸𝜋𝑠𝑘𝑟𝜎11𝛿1subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑞𝑟\displaystyle=\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}0\leq k\leq\min\{c,2t-s\}\\ 0\leq r\leq R\\ p_{k}+q_{r}<\delta\end{subarray}}E_{\pi}(s,k,r,\sigma,1-\frac{1-\delta}{1-p_{k}-q_{r}}),
pksubscript𝑝𝑘\displaystyle p_{k} =1−(∑i=0k(ci)​(1m​⌊α​s​mnm​i​n⌋)i​(1−1m​⌊α​s​mnm​i​n⌋)c−i)R,absent1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑘binomial𝑐𝑖superscript1𝑚𝛼𝑠𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑖superscript11𝑚𝛼𝑠𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑐𝑖𝑅\displaystyle=1-\left(\sum_{i=0}^{k}\binom{c}{i}\left(\frac{1}{m}\lfloor\frac{\alpha sm}{n_{min}}\rfloor\right)^{i}\left(1-\frac{1}{m}\lfloor\frac{\alpha sm}{n_{min}}\rfloor\right)^{c-i}\right)^{R},
qrsubscript𝑞𝑟\displaystyle q_{r} =1−(∑i=0r(Ri)​(1m​⌊α​s​mnm​i​n⌋)i​(1−1m​⌊α​s​mnm​i​n⌋)R−i)nm​a​x,absent1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑟binomial𝑅𝑖superscript1𝑚𝛼𝑠𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑖superscript11𝑚𝛼𝑠𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑅𝑖subscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥\displaystyle=1-\left(\sum_{i=0}^{r}\binom{R}{i}\left(\frac{1}{m}\lfloor\frac{\alpha sm}{n_{min}}\rfloor\right)^{i}\left(1-\frac{1}{m}\lfloor\frac{\alpha sm}{n_{min}}\rfloor\right)^{R-i}\right)^{n_{max}},

with σ𝜎\sigma the noise multiplier used in π𝜋\pi, Eπ​(⋅)subscript𝐸𝜋⋅E_{\pi}(\cdot) the privacy accounting method of π𝜋\pi, and nm​a​xsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥n_{max} the maximum possible size of the population.

Proof.

The proof closely resembles that of Corollary 2, with the exception of the calculation of 1−qr1subscript𝑞𝑟1-q_{r}, which represents a lower bound on the probability that all clients in the population are selected for at most r𝑟r rounds (i.e., event B𝐵B). Considering the server’s predictability, we could not get a bound as tight as that of Client-Centric. Instead, the equation is

Pr⁡[B]Pr𝐵\displaystyle\Pr[B] =(∑i=0r(Ri)​(1m​⌊α​s​mnm​i​n⌋)i​(1−1m​⌊α​s​mnm​i​n⌋)R−i)nabsentsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑟binomial𝑅𝑖superscript1𝑚𝛼𝑠𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑖superscript11𝑚𝛼𝑠𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑅𝑖𝑛\displaystyle=\left(\sum_{i=0}^{r}\binom{R}{i}\left(\frac{1}{m}\lfloor\frac{\alpha sm}{n_{min}}\rfloor\right)^{i}\left(1-\frac{1}{m}\lfloor\frac{\alpha sm}{n_{min}}\rfloor\right)^{R-i}\right)^{n}

=1−qr.absent1subscript𝑞𝑟\displaystyle=1-q_{r}.

The corollary follows when one substitutes this lower bound of Pr⁡[B]Pr𝐵\Pr[B] with that used in the proof of Corollary 2 and follows the remainder of that proof. ∎

To visualize the difference between the bounds presented in Corollary 2 and 3, we once again refer to the practical example discussed earlier (section 3.6). In the case of Server-Centric, we set nm​a​xsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥n_{max} to 109superscript10910^{9}, which we consider to be the physical limit for the number of devices in the real world. Figure 12 illustrates the variation in their privacy cost, demonstrating a slight increase in cost across all evaluated scenarios. For instance, in the case of dealing with a population of size 2×1052superscript1052\times 10^{5} when employing the same noise multiplier during training on FEMNIST, Client-Centric ensures a privacy cost of ϵ=1.8italic-ϵ1.8\epsilon=1.8, whereas Server-Centric results in a higher cost of ϵ=2.3italic-ϵ2.3\epsilon=2.3.

Appendix E Execution Efficiency of Informed Selection

Figure 13 and Figure 14 present a comparison between Lotto’s informed selection and Oort in terms of average time cost and network footprint at the server end during a training round, respectively. When compared to Oort, the Lotto implementation using the Client-Centric approach incurs a time cost of less than 5%, 10%, and 5% for population sizes of 100, 400, and 700, respectively. Additionally, the overhead for Server-Centric is 2%, 0%, and 0%, respectively. Regarding the network footprint, Lotto introduces less than 1% additional network footprint across all evaluated tasks and participation scales. The observed trend indicates that Lotto maintains an acceptable time cost and negligible network overhead during informed selection, similar to the findings in random selection (section 5.2).
